# NixNa (*Remove your NAs in one second)*

Why NixNa

-   Dealing with missing data is an important step in data cleaning

-   With a large data set we might need to remove rows with Nas

-   This will clean our data and prepare us for the next steps

## Install the Package

Install and load the NixNa package from CRAN

install the development version from GitHub

devtools::install_github("sarraalii/NixNa")

library(NixNa)

# Function 1

trimNa: Remove rows with missing values conditional on a specified column

## Example trimNA()

-   Testing the trimNa function to remove countries with missing MatMort values

-   finaldata1 \<- trimna(finaldata, target_col = "country_name", condition_col = "MatMort")

This will remove rows from country_name column conditional on MatMort missing data

# Function 2

trimcovNa: Remove rows with missing values in specified covariate column

## Example trimcovNa()

-   Test by defining the target column and covariate columns

-   target_column \<- "country_name"

-   covariate_columns \<- c("GDP", "male_edu", "temp")

-   Use the redefined function to clean the finaldata dataset

-   cleaned_covariates \<- trimcovNa(finaldata, target_col = target_column, covariate_cols = covariate_columns)

## Data Description

finaldata loads with the package

|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
|------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Data to demonstrate the trimNa and trimcovNa function Description: Data for 181 countries from the Uppsala Conflict Data Program and World Bank for the years 2000 to 2019. The dataset includes various socio-economic indicators. |

## Conclusion

-   Data cleanliness is essential for accurate and reliable results in data analysis.

-   Care should be taken to choose appropriate methods for handling missing data based on the nature of the dataset and the analysis goals.

-   The process of handling missing data is a key preprocessing step that contributes to the overall data quality and integrity.

-   A well-cleaned dataset sets the foundation for effective and meaningful insights during the data analysis pipeline.
